From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

Catalan

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Borrowed from Latin rugīre (“roar”). First attested in the 19th century.[1]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): (Central, Balearic) [ruˈʒi]
  • IPA(key): (Valencia) [ruˈd͡ʒiɾ]
  • Audio (Barcelona):(file)

Verb

[edit]

rugir (first-person singular present rugeixo, first-person singular preterite rugí, past participle rugit)

  1. (intransitive) to roar

Conjugation

[edit]
    Conjugation of rugir (third conjugation, with -eix-)

plural rugits rugides

preterite rugí rugires rugí rugírem rugíreu rugiren
conditional rugiria rugiries rugiria rugiríem rugiríeu rugirien

vostè 		nosaltres
nós 		vosaltres
vós 		ells/elles

Related terms

[edit]
  • rugit

References

[edit]
  1. ^ “rugir”, in Gran Diccionari de la Llengua Catalana, Grup Enciclopèdia Catalana, 2025

Further reading

[edit]
  • “rugir”, in Diccionari de la llengua catalana [Dictionary of the Catalan Language] (in Catalan), second edition, Institute of Catalan Studies [Catalan: Institut d'Estudis Catalans], April 2007
  • “rugir” in Diccionari normatiu valencià, Acadèmia Valenciana de la Llengua.
  • “rugir” in Diccionari català-valencià-balear, Antoni Maria Alcover and Francesc de Borja Moll, 1962.

French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Borrowed from Latin rugīre (“roar”). Cf. Old French ruir, a more gallicized variant. See also rut.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ʁy.ʒiʁ/
  • Audio (France (Lyon)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Lyon)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Vosges)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Somain)):(file)

Verb

[edit]

rugir

  1. to roar

Conjugation

[edit]

This is a regular verb of the second conjugation, like finir, choisir, and most other verbs with infinitives ending in -ir. One salient feature of this conjugation is the repeated appearance of the infix -iss-.

1 The French gerund is usable only with the preposition en.
2 In less formal writing or speech, these tenses may be found to have been replaced in the following way:
past historic → present perfect
past anterior → pluperfect
imperfect subjunctive → present subjunctive
pluperfect subjunctive → past subjunctive

(Christopher Kendris [1995], Master the Basics: French, pp. 77, 78, 79, 81).

Derived terms

[edit]
  • rugissement

Further reading

[edit]
  • “rugir”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

Portuguese

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Probably borrowed from Latin rugīre (“to roar”).

Pronunciation

[edit]
 
  • (Brazil) IPA(key): /ʁuˈʒi(ʁ)/ [huˈʒi(h)]
  • (Brazil) IPA(key): /ʁuˈʒi(ʁ)/ [huˈʒi(h)]
    • (São Paulo) IPA(key): /ʁuˈʒi(ɾ)/ [huˈʒi(ɾ)]
    • (Rio de Janeiro) IPA(key): /ʁuˈʒi(ʁ)/ [χuˈʒi(χ)]
    • (Southern Brazil) IPA(key): /ʁuˈʒi(ɻ)/ [huˈʒi(ɻ)]
 
  • (Portugal) IPA(key): /ʁuˈʒiɾ/
  • (Portugal) IPA(key): /ʁuˈʒiɾ/
    • (Southern Portugal) IPA(key): /ʁuˈʒi.ɾi/

Verb

[edit]

rugir (first-person singular present rujo, first-person singular preterite rugi, past participle rugido)

  1. to roar (to make a loud, deep cry)

Conjugation

[edit]
    Conjugation of rugir (g-j alternation) (See Appendix:Portuguese verbs)

(eu) 		Second-person
(tu) 		Third-person

Related terms

[edit]
  • ruído

Spanish

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Borrowed from Latin rugīre (“roar”). Compare the inherited Old Spanish (and Ladino) ruir; cf. also the related ruido.[1]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ruˈxiɾ/ [ruˈxiɾ]
  • Rhymes: -iɾ
  • Syllabification: ru‧gir

Verb

[edit]

rugir (first-person singular present rujo, first-person singular preterite rugí, past participle rugido)

  1. to roar
    Synonym: bramar
  2. to bellow
  3. to rumble

Conjugation

[edit]
    Conjugation of rugir (g-j alternation) (See Appendix:Spanish verbs)

gerund rugiendo
past participle masculine feminine
singular rugido rugida
plural rugidos rugidas

1Rare; now chiefly used in legal language.
2Argentine and Uruguayan voseo prefers the tuteo-form for the present subjunctive.
